intro: Phaeanthus acuminatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved phaeanthus, is a flowering plant native to parts of Central America. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, strap-like leaves and clusters of bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories. Its flowers are usually white or pale blue and bloom in the spring or early summer. It is valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in partially shaded conditions.
